title.value: Interacting brains revisited: A cross-brain network neuroscience perspective
title.justification: The title provides an overview of the paper's focus on cross-brain network neuroscience and interactions between brains.
title.quote: Interacting brains revisited: A cross-brain network neuroscience perspective

extractions.description: The paper presents a framework for studying interbrain networks using bipartite graphs, focusing on understanding the neural basis of social interactions. It explores interbrain synchrony and its potential to predict social characteristics using machine learning techniques.

type.justification: The paper involves the application of machine learning techniques on empirical data to study brain interactions.
type.quote: We demonstrate the proposed analytical framework and evaluate its utility using a functional near-infrared spectroscopy (fNIRS) hyperscanning data set.

name.justification: The research focuses on the neural basis of social interactions, making it a part of neuroscience.
name.quote: Elucidating the neural basis of social behavior is a long-standing challenge in neuroscience.

name.justification: The paper utilizes machine learning techniques to analyze interbrain synchrony and predict social characteristics.
name.quote: Beyond inferential inquiries, we demonstrate that graph representations can be used to predict individual social characteristics.

name.justification: The use of network models and graph-based analysis to understand brain interactions places it within network science.
name.quote: Network models have provided new insights into the neural basis of social behavior.

name.justification: Graph2Vec is cited as a method used for generating network embeddings in the study.
name.quote: Graph2Vec (Narayanan et al., 2017) is a skipgram-based embedding that decomposes each graph into nonlinear substructures.

is_contributed.justification: Graph2Vec is referenced from external work and not introduced in this paper for the first time.

is_executed.justification: The paper indicates the implementation of Graph2Vec to generate embeddings of interbrain networks.
is_executed.quote: The embeddings were then input into classifiers. Here, we applied a L2-regularized logistic regression classifier.

is_compared.justification: Graph2Vec's performance is compared with other embeddings for prediction tasks.
is_compared.quote: The performance of our network representation was compared with state-of-the-art network embeddings.

referenced_paper_title.value: graph2vec: Learning distributed representations of graphs
referenced_paper_title.justification: The reference to Graph2Vec includes its contribution title in the comparisons made in the paper.

name.justification: GL2Vec is mentioned as one of the embeddings used for predicting task conditions in the study.
name.quote: Graph and Line graph to vector (GL2Vec; Chen & Koga, 2019), which uses the edge-adjacency matrix to reformulate the underlying graphs as line graphs.

is_contributed.justification: GL2Vec is referenced from existing literature, indicating it is not contributed by this paper.

is_executed.justification: The embeddings, including GL2Vec, are implemented and executed within the paper's experiments.
is_executed.quote: The embeddings were then input into classifiers.

is_compared.justification: GL2Vec's performance is compared against other network embeddings in classification tasks.
is_compared.quote: Our NMF-based approach outperformed all network embeddings as well as the functional connectivity estimators.

referenced_paper_title.value: Graph and Line Graph to Vector (GL2Vec)
referenced_paper_title.justification: The title captures GL2Vec as one of the methods used and compared in the research analysis.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Graph and Line graph to vector (GL2Vec; Chen & Koga, 2019)

name.justification: GeoScattering is another embedding method employed for evaluating the prediction of social characteristics in the paper.
name.quote: applied the geometric scattering embedding (Gao et al., 2019), which performs (signal-) processing on graphs.

is_contributed.justification: GeoScattering is cited from external sources, showing it is not an original contribution of the paper.

is_executed.justification: The approach is implemented as part of the study's comparison of various network embeddings.
is_executed.quote: The embeddings were then input into classifiers.

is_compared.justification: GeoScattering's performance is measured against other embeddings and models within the paper.
is_compared.quote: GeoScattering reached competitive results in regime (ii).

referenced_paper_title.value: Geometric scattering for graph data analysis
referenced_paper_title.justification: The reference to GeoScattering includes its source used in comparison of methods.
referenced_paper_title.quote: applied the geometric scattering embedding (Gao et al., 2019)

name.justification: NMF is applied for decomposing networks into components and is central to the paper's methodology.
name.quote: The coefficient matrix was then analyzed within a multivariate Bayesian hierarchical model (BHM).

is_contributed.justification: NMF is a well-established machine learning technique, not first introduced by this paper.
is_contributed.quote: Based on these estimators, a bipartite graph can be constructed from two sets of nodes represented by personâ€™s brain regions.

is_executed.justification: The paper implements NMF to analyze network components from interbrain graph representations.
is_executed.quote: To jointly learn a low dimensional representation across all graphs, NMF was applied to the vectorized nodal metrics.

is_compared.justification: While used comprehensively, NMF is part of the proposed analysis framework and is not separately compared to other techniques in terms of performance.
is_compared.quote: NMF was able to decompose the global density effect into subsets of nodes showing particular distinct result patterns.

referenced_paper_title.value: Learning the Parts of Objects by Non-Negative Matrix Factorization
referenced_paper_title.justification: The NMF technique is referenced originallly as described by Lee & Seung (1999).
referenced_paper_title.quote: the nonnegative matrix factorization (NMF; Lee & Seung, 1999)

name.justification: LDP is used as one of the graph embedding techniques to analyze structural roles of nodes in the study.
name.quote: Local degree profile (LDP; Cai & Wang, 2018) is a simple embedding that is calculated based on five topological features.

is_contributed.justification: LDP is cited from existing literature and used for comparative analysis, not developed in the paper.

is_executed.justification: LDP is utilized in the study to implement graph-based analyses of interbrain networks.
is_executed.quote: The embeddings were then input into classifiers.

is_compared.justification: LDP's performance is compared with other network embedding methods within the study results.
is_compared.quote: consistently outperformed by our NMF-based approach

referenced_paper_title.value: A Simple Yet Effective Baseline for Non-attributed Graph Classification
referenced_paper_title.justification: The title is associated with LDP's use as referenced in the analysis conducted.

name.justification: WCO is used as a connectivity estimator to formulate interbrain networks in the paper.
name.quote: bivariate wavelet coherence (WCO; Torrence & Compo, 1998) was calculated via the continuous wavelet transformation.

is_contributed.justification: WCO is a previously established method used within the paper's framework but not introduced by the paper itself.

is_executed.justification: WCO is applied to calcuate connectivity based on wavelet transformation as part of the data analysis.
is_executed.quote: bivariate wavelet coherence (WCO; Torrence & Compo, 1998) was calculated via the continuous wavelet transformation.

is_compared.justification: While integral to the method, WCO itself is not compared numerically with other connectivity estimators in the study.
is_compared.quote: decided to exemplify this framework using the widely applied WCO

referenced_paper_title.value: A Practical Guide to Wavelet Analysis
referenced_paper_title.justification: The reference indicates the foundational paper of the WCO technique as used in analysis.

name.justification: BHM is used as a model to analyze the results obtained from network embeddings to provide insights about interbrain synchrony.
name.quote: The coefficients of these components are then analyzed within a multivariate Bayesian hierarchical model (BHM).

is_contributed.justification: BHM is a statistical method applied in the study, not a novel contribution of the paper.
is_contributed.quote: Bayesian analysis goes beyond the point estimates of a frequentist approach by allowing a probability statement to be derived.

is_executed.justification: BHM is executed to analyze the network properties derived from the decomposed graphs.
is_executed.quote: multivariate Bayesian hierarchical model (BHM), thereby integrating all nodal effects into a single model

is_compared.justification: BHM is applied for analysis within the study but not as part of a numerical comparison with other statistical models.
is_compared.quote: Bayesian analysis goes beyond the point estimates of a frequentist approach by allowing a probability statement to be derived.

referenced_paper_title.justification: The reference to BHM includes its application in analysis as evidenced in the text.

name.justification: The fNIRS hyperscanning data set is the main empirical data used for analysis in the study.
name.quote: evaluate its utility using a functional near-infrared spectroscopy (fNIRS) hyperscanning data set with a well-established hyperscanning design.

referenced_paper_title.value: Brain-to-brain synchrony in parent-child dyads and the relationship with emotion regulation revealed by fNIRS-based hyperscanning
referenced_paper_title.justification: The data set is described as part of previously established research as indicated in the reference.
referenced_paper_title.quote: evaluate its utility using a functional near-infrared spectroscopy (fNIRS) hyperscanning data set with a well-established hyperscanning design (for more details, see Reindl et al., 2018).
